title: How can immigration affect a country's economy? - Quora

response.answer_text: You are asking a very broad question. There are many different types of migrants in many different countries, so there can be no generalizations. Let’s take Singapore as an example. Singapore accepts a very large number of immigrants. Singapore prioritizes immigration on the basis of the skills the country needs and the skills the migrant applicant offers. As a result, immigration is extremely beneficial both to Singapore’s economy and to the immigrants. It is a win-win arrangement. Now let’s look at Syria’s emigrants in its neighboring countries (particularly Jordan, Lebanon, and Turkey). They have fled Syria under extremely adverse conditions. Some live in refugee camps in bad conditions and depend on international largess for their survival. Others seek whatever jobs they can find in these nations’ cities. This is a lose-lose arrangement. Immigration to other nations generally falls somewhere in between these two extremes. Much depends on whether the immigration is by legal or illegal means, their level of education, and whether they are refugees or immigrants seeking better opportunities in life. There are many well-educated immigrants who came to their new country under favorable conditions who contribute very favorably to their host country’s economy. Those with low levels of education who had to flee their country with barely the clothes on their back often require considerable welfare assistance at least during the early period of their arrival. A country’s immigration policy can have significant influence on the outcome. Singapore has a very business-oriented immigration policy which benefits the country. The United States’ immigration policy has been outdated for close to half a century and is thereby dysfunctional, which has been a major source of the controversy and problems related to immigration in the U.S.
